Situation1: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: Late-evening music plans overlap with the building’s quiet hours while a neighbor’s windows are open.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I wiped down the kitchen counter, the lemony scent of cleaner lingering in the air. As the housekeeping cleaner, I was expected to keep the apartment spotless, but with my busy schedule, I often only managed to tidy up the visible mess and do a quick sweep of the shared spaces. Tonight, though, my mind was elsewhere. My friends and I had planned a late-evening music session in my living room—a rare chance to unwind. But as I set up the speakers, I noticed my neighbor’s windows were wide open, and the building’s quiet hours had just begun. As a citizen, I knew I should respect the rules and my neighbors’ right to peace. Yet, I felt torn. I wanted to enjoy my evening, but I also didn’t want to be the reason someone’s rest was disturbed. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each expectation pulling me in a different direction, and I stood there, music in hand, caught between what I wanted and what I knew was right.
